Mongolia: Logistics Capacity Development

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Mongolia has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to 
provide technical assistance (TA) for capacity development in logistics. During the fact-finding 
mission in March 2012, ADB and the government reached an understanding on the impact, 
outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs, financing arrangements, and terms of 
reference  for  consulting  services  for  the  TA.1 The  design  and  monitoring  framework  is  in 
Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  As  a  landlocked  country,  Mongolia  must  rely  on  the  Russian  Federation  and  the 
People’s Republic of China for access to seaports. In the last 10 years, surging import and 
export traffic has exceeded Mongolia’s logistics capacity, both physical and managerial, causing 
severe delays and excessive transport costs that increase the cost of products and services and 
inhibit economic development. Mongolia has only basic freight transport and handling services, 
as reflected in its overall logistics performance index ranking of 141 (1 is best and 155 is worst), 
indicating  that  logistics  is  underdeveloped  and  constrains  Mongolia’s  competitiveness  and 
economic development.2 
 
3.  ADB’s country partnership strategy for Mongolia cites high transit costs and low reliability 
of  logistics  chains  as  constraining  the  country’s  competitiveness  and  limiting  regional 
cooperation.3 ADB’s regional cooperation strategy and program update for the Central Asia 
Regional Economic Cooperation initiative identifies multimodal transport as a strategic priority 
and the development of multimodal terminals as key interventions needing ADB support.4 
 
4.  Ulaanbaatar is the main trade and transportation hub of Mongolia, its terminals handling 
95% of the nation’s exports and imports. The growth of the mining industry, especially in the 
Gobi region, will increase infrastructure development needs significantly. 
 
5.  Demand for freight transportation is driven by economic growth, with growth in imports 
closely tracking growth in overall economic activity and import growth projections indicating the 
need  for  improved  logistics.  The  economy  grew  by  17.3%  in  2011  driven  mainly  by 
infrastructure spending related to mining activity. Imports surged owing to the equipment and 
machinery needs of mining. The economy is forecast to continue growing at double digit rates, 
15% in 2012 and 17.5% in 2013,5 indicating a growing need for freight traffic handling and 
logistics. Based on the past close link between economic growth and container traffic growth, it 
is expected that on average container traffic will grow by at least 15% to 20% per annum over 
the next 10 years. 
 
6.  Demand for logistics facilities and warehouses is already very high in Ulaanbaatar, 
where existing freight terminals have no space for expansion. The city government plans to 
relocate  all  freight  terminals  to  outlying  sites  and  reallocate  the  cleared  land  for  housing. 
Relocation will eliminate problems generated by excessive freight traffic in the city center.  
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 30 November 2011. 
2  World  Bank.  2011.  Logistics  Performance  Index.  http://info.worldbank.org/etools/tradesurvey/mode1b.asp 
(accessed on 19 April 2012). 
3  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2012–2016. Manila. 
4  ADB. 2005. Central Asia Regional Cooperation Strategy and Program Update, 2006–2008: Development Through

5  ADB. 2012. Asian Development Outlook 2012: Confronting Rising Inequality in Asia. Manila.

2   
7.  Mongolia’s  logistics  industry  has  great  potential  for  development.  At  present,  no 
regulations govern freight forwarding. Constraints on truck access to terminals during the day, 
logistics  terminals’  lack  of  consolidation,  rapidly  deteriorating  infrastructure  and  material 
handling equipment, and unreliable and poor service are some of the challenges facing the 
industry. Multimodal cargo handling capacity in Ulaanbaatar is nearly saturated. Ineffective 
multimodal container handling practices cause very slow container turnaround time and poor flat 
wagon  utilization.  Consequently,  freight  forwarders  incur  high  demurrage  charges,  which 
contribute to Mongolia’s high logistics cost. Railway and multimodal terminal operators urgently 
require assistance in adopting modern logistics management and introducing efficient container 
transport and distribution techniques to address this escalating problem. 
 
8.  Until recently, ADB assistance for transport in Mongolia has largely been for the road 
subsector. However, given the importance of logistics in the comprehensive development of the 
country’s transport system, ADB is increasing its support in this area, mainly by supporting the 
development of two modern logistics terminals: (i) the logistics terminal at Zamyn-Uud under the 
ADB-financed  Regional  Logistics  Development  Project,6 and  (ii)  the  integrated  multimodal 
logistics facility in Ulaanbaatar (under preparation). 
 
9.  While these facilities will provide modern multimodal logistics infrastructure, government 
capacity will need to be developed to ensure their efficient management and operationalization. 
The proposed capacity development TA will improve the management of existing terminals and 
operations and enhance the utilization of their physical capacity. At present, the Ministry of 
Roads, Transportation, Construction, and Urban Development (MRTCUD), which has primary 
responsibility for logistics in Mongolia, has very limited capacity for performing its responsibility 
for logistics development. Ministry officials need training and capacity building to acquire the 
requisite logistics management knowledge and skills. 
 
10.  Considerable  scope  exists  to  explore  public–private  partnership  (PPP)  in  logistics 
development and operations.7  International experience demonstrates that the private sector is 
more efficient and client-oriented in delivering logistics services. Under PPP arrangements, 
private sector operators can become the providers of services, with responsibility for designing, 
building, operating, and possibly financing the assets needed to deliver services. The role of the 
government  agencies  in  the  public  sector  can  be  regulation,  performance  monitoring,  and 
contract management. A Law of Mongolia on Concessions was passed by the Parliament of 
Mongolia in January 2010 and has provided an initial basis for logistics development through 
PPP  models.8 The  government  has  little  experience  with  PPPs,  however,  so  it  will  need 
guidance and support in developing projects through PPP arrangements.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
11.  This is the first ADB TA intervention targeting logistics capacity development in Mongolia. 
The TA will support logistics development, which will play a key role in the country’s economic 
development. The premise of the TA is that enhanced capacity to develop efficient and effective 
logistics infrastructure and services is needed to ensure sustained economic development. As 
                                                 
6  ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan and Grant to 
Mongolia for the Regional Logistics Development Project. Manila (Loan 2719-MON and Grant 0240-MON). 
7  PPP combines the public and private sectors to deliver a project or service traditionally provided by either the 
public or the private sector. PPPs recognize that both the private and the public sector have certain advantages 
over the other, depending on the task. By assigning roles where each sector has a comparative advantage, public 
services and infrastructure can be provided efficiently. 
8  Government of Mongolia. 2010. Law of Mongolia on Concessions. http://www.ppp.mn/

3
the government will continue in its policy and regulatory role supporting logistics development, 
enhancing its capacity is vital. The TA will support opportunities for private sector participation to 
enhance operational efficiencies in logistics.  
 
12.  The TA will address the following areas: 
(i)  Institutional  strengthening.  The  TA  will  establish  a  dedicated  unit  under 
MRTCUD  to  guide  the  government  on  policy  and  regulatory  matters.  It  will 
explore the potential for setting up an agency that has the authority to coordinate, 
directly  and  indirectly,  the  various  stakeholders  in  transport  and  logistics 
development, help streamline the approval of new initiatives, and provide a one-
stop shop for advice, consultancy, and dispute resolution. 
(ii)  Partnering with the private sector. The TA will explore ways to encourage and 
incentivize private sector participation in the development of logistics facilities, 
including examining PPP models for developing logistics terminals, reviewing 
international experience in logistics policy and sector development, and providing 
guidance  and  support  for  the  government’s  preparation  of  PPP  concession 
agreements.  
(iii)  Building consensus. The TA will support training programs and workshops that 
will allow transport and logistics stakeholders to discuss issues with experts and 
come to a better understanding of possible logistics solutions for Mongolia. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The impact will be improved logistics performance of Mongolia. The outcome will be 
strengthened capacity of MRTCUD for logistics sector planning, execution, and management. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
14.  The TA will have three outputs: (i) a dedicated logistics unit established under MRTCUD, 
(ii) PPP development and support for the implementation of the Ulaanbaatar Logistics Terminal, 
and (iii) a logistics database for Mongolia. 
 
15.  Output  1:  Logistics  unit.  Output  1  will  strengthen  the  management  capacity  of 
MRTCUD and its agencies for logistics development in Mongolia. Activities will cover all areas 
of logistics policy and infrastructure development and implementation, including  
(i)  providing advice, support, and on-the-job training to government officials;  
(ii)  developing an institutional plan for better interagency coordination;  
(iii)  identifying priority reforms for improving logistics operations; and 
(iv)  directly  supporting  and  building  management  capability  in  the  project 
implementation unit responsible for the Ulaanbaatar Logistics Terminal Project 
and subsequent projects. 
 
16.  Output  2:  Public–private  partnership  capacity  building  and  opportunities  in 
logistics. Output 2, in cooperation with the private sector, will help develop PPP opportunities in 
logistics development in Mongolia. Activities will include 
(i)  developing  a  financing  strategy  for  attracting  private  sector  participation  in 
logistics and the provision of logistics services; 
(ii)  providing advice for developing PPP concession agreements; 
(iii)  organizing PPP training for government officials; and

4   
(iv)  convening two workshops, which will serve as platforms for brainstorming and 
exchanging ideas between policy makers and other stakeholders, including the 
private sector. 
 
17.  Output 3: Logistics database. Output 3 will create a logistics database that tracks 
logistics and freight information. Activities will include 
(i)  establishing a logistics database that tracks traffic volume by mode, 
(ii)  using data to develop a national logistics strategy and priority project list, and  
(iii)  assisting the government in screening project proposals for feasibility.   
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $900,000 and will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan 
Fund for Poverty Reduction and administered by ADB. The government will provide counterpart 
support  in  the  form  of  suitably  furnished  offices  with  utilities;  telecommunications  access; 
materials, maps, data, and documents required by the TA; counterpart professional and support 
staff; and other in-kind contributions. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  MRTCUD will be the executing agency. As the ministry responsible for road, rail, and air 
transportation; construction; and urban development, it has been the executing agency for a 
number of ADB TA and investment projects. TA implementation will build on the experience and 
lessons gained from ongoing TA projects. A steering committee established by MRTCUD and 
chaired  by  the  state  secretary  will  guide  the  TA  and  monitor  its  progress.  Officials  from 
MRTCUD, the municipal government (the mayor’s office), the City Planning Department, and 
Ulaanbaatar Railway Company will be on the steering committee. Private sector participation on 
the steering committee will be encouraged. 
 
20.  The TA will require 51 person-months of national and 14 person-months of international 
consulting services. The terms of reference are in Appendix 3. ADB will engage individual 
consultants in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time).  
 
21.  Disbursement will follow ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The TA will be implemented over 24 months, from 15 August 20129 
to 15 August 2014. Equipment will be procured by the consultants in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time) and transferred to MRTCUD 
upon TA completion. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $900,000 to the Government 
of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for the 
Logistics Capacity Development, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
                                                 
9  The delayed start date is owing to national elections in Mongolia scheduled on 28 June 2012.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  General 
 
1.  The  consultants  will  perform  their  tasks  in  consultation  with  the  Ministry  of  Roads, 
Transportation,  Construction,  and  Urban  Development  (MRTCUD)  and  other  national 
government agencies to ensure full acceptance of the outcome of the technical assistance (TA). 
The TA will require 65 person-months of consulting services (14 person-months international 
and 51 person-months national) over 24 months. The following specialists will be recruited: 
(i)  transport logistics specialist (8 person-months, international); 
(ii)  finance specialist for public–private partnerships (PPPs) in logistics (6 person-
months, international); 
(iii)  logistics cell coordinator (24 person-months, national); 
(iv)  institutional coordination specialist (12 person-months, national); and 
(v)  capacity development associate (15 person-months, national). 
 
B.  Scope of Work 
 
2.  The TA will (i) support and guide the government in the development and management 
of logistics facilities; and (ii) assist the government on all aspects of logistics planning and 
decision making, including training for government staff and stakeholders. 
 
C.  Specific Tasks 
 
1.  Team  Leader  and  Transport  Logistics  Specialist  (international, 8 person- 
months) 
 
3.  The specialist will (i) be a well-qualified logistics specialist, (ii) have at least 15 years of 
project management experience in transport logistics, (iii) have a successful track record in 
leading a team of experts on similar assignments in Mongolia or similar countries, (iv) be fully 
knowledgeable of Asian Development Bank (ADB) procedures, and (v) be fluent in English. The 
specialist must also (i) have at least 15 years of international work experience in logistics; (ii) be 
familiar with the international best practices in the design, construction, and operation of cross-
border  multimodal  transport  and  logistics  facilities;  and  (iii)  be  familiar  with  private  sector 
engagement for operating such facilities.     
 
4.  The  specialist’s  duties  will  be  twofold.  As  team  leader,  the  specialist  will  use  the 
knowledge and experience of previous projects to establish work arrangements and take overall 
responsibility  for  team  performance.  Supported  by  a  team  of  international  and  national 
consultants, the team leader will 
(i)  provide executing and implementing agencies with guidance and expert advice; 
(ii)  oversee  and  coordinate  the  work  of  all  consultants  engaged,  monitor  their 
performance, and initiate corrective action if necessary; and 
(iii)  develop  and  help  implement  project  implementation  monitoring  and  control 
procedures. 
 
5.  As a transport logistics specialist, the consultant will 
(i)  provide guidance to MRTCUD for logistics management; 
(ii)  review the existing railway and road transshipment and logistics facilities toward 
maximizing their effectiveness; 
(iii)  establish a logistics database that tracks traffic volume by mode; 
(iv)  use data to develop a national logistics strategy and priority project list;

Appendix 3  9 
(v)  assist the government in screening project proposals for feasibility; 
(vi)  prepare  guidelines  for  integrating  the  best  international  practices  for  facility 
operations; 
(vii)  provide advice and assistance on starting up, commissioning, and testing newly 
constructed logistics terminals; 
(viii)  review existing institutional arrangements, recommend how to strengthen them, 
and develop and execute capacity development programs; 
(ix)  organize training sessions and workshops and conduct training for MRTCUD, 
Mongolian Railway Authority, and other government agencies; and 
(x)  provide guidance to incentivize private sector participation in terminal operations, 
equipment leasing, warehousing, and light manufacturing. 
 
2.  Finance Specialist for Public–Private Partnerships in Logistics (6 person-
months, international) 
 
6.  The specialist should have experience in structuring private sector participation in the 
building, development, and operation of logistics terminals and involvement in at least two 
logistics terminal projects. The specialist will be responsible for exploring ways to encourage 
and incentivize private sector participation in the development of logistics facilities. Tasks will 
include the following: 
(i)  Identify a list of PPP opportunities in logistics in Mongolia. 
(ii)  Provide recommendations to the government taking into account the capacity of 
the domestic private finance sector and domestic contractors to participate in 
PPPs and propose how to enhance their capacity. 
(iii)  Prioritize the opportunities under the investments planned for logistics. 
(iv)  Support  the  development  of  evaluation  criteria  and  bid  documents  for  PPP 
projects in logistics. 
(v)  Assess risks by (a) reviewing current risk allocation under the model concession 
agreements  and  (b)  proposing  changes  in  risk  allocation  that  will  make  the 
concessions more attractive to the private sector without significantly increasing 
liabilities on the government. 
(vi)  Propose  appropriate  viability  enhancement  mechanisms  and  investment 
schemes  such  as  equity  financing,  parallel  loan  financing,  partial  credit 
guarantees, and political risk guarantees for consideration by ADB and other 
agencies.  Outline  how  these  contributions  can  help  meet  public  and  private 
financing requirements for creating viable PPPs. 
(vii)  Facilitate the training of government staff likely to be involved in PPP projects by 
exposing them to actual PPP projects under processing in the region (e.g., a 
1-week study course on actual PPP projects in logistics). 
 
3.  Logistics Cell Coordinator (24 person-months, national) 
 
7.  The coordinator should have a bachelor’s degree in communications, planning, project 
management, or related fields and at least 3 years of relevant experience in communications, 
project management, and/or office management. The coordinator should have strong word 
processing and data management skills, including proficiency with Microsoft Excel, Word, and 
PowerPoint; proficiency with website development is preferred. The coordinator should have 
excellent verbal and written communication skills in English and Mongolian and the ability to 
work as a team player in a dynamic project environment.

6.  Resource Persons (international and national experts, including ADB staff) 
 
12.  External expert advice and the specialized analytical inputs of international and national 
resource persons may be needed to  
(i)  review draft inputs,  
(ii)  conduct special technical sessions,  
(iii)  facilitate and provide expert inputs in workshops and seminars, and 
(iv)  perform other specialized tasks required by the TA implementation team.  
 
13.  Depending upon the task, and as required by ADB, resource persons including ADB 
staff will provide inputs from their own offices at ADB headquarters and may participate in 
missions.  
 
D.  Reporting and Workshops 
 
14.  The  consultants  will  organize  an  inception  meeting  and  two  workshops,  which  will 
include  high-level  consultation  with  key  policy  makers  and  other  sector  stakeholders.  The 
inception meeting will review the inception report and provide guidance to the consultants for 
implementing the various tasks specified under the terms of reference. The consultants will 
provide periodic progress reports to ADB and the government.
